review_title: Best if you get in with the right people
job_title: Coordinator of Moves and Setups in Dallas, TX
pros: Some of the best times I had were at DBU. Vacation and insurance were good
cons: Pay was horrible. Ran my own department and was paid 35k per year working 50~ hours a week. Compensation for hard work sometimes happened but not a lot. Basically was told I was apart of a service industry and that I could never tell someone no, no matter how ridiculous the request. I didn’t kiss enough butt to get paid more or move up the hill but I still got my job done right and well.

pros: Staff is dedicated to their vision!

review_title: DBU is great! Just a little redundant
pros:

job_title: Assistant to the Director in Dallas, TX
pros: It was a great position to get started in my career. I learned a lot of valuable workplace lessons, while having some schooling paid for. I would encourage anyone who is toward the end of their college career to explore the opportunity of working for the university, as I do feel I greatly benefited from my time there as a full-time staff member.
cons: Unfortunately, was not offered opportunities for growth despite receiving encouraging messages from leadership of the "opportunities" for me there. I was an exemplary employee, teachable, and quick to make corrections, while also being respectful and hard working. When I expressed multiple times interest for positions with a higher level of responsibility, I was met with a "not the right position for you" sort of response, and that they thought my ideal role would be as an assistant.

review_title: Pays very less to student workers

pros: It is an encouraging environment and everyone is nice
cons: There are no cons to working here

pros: Being a student workers allows people to get more experience in a given field to know if it is something they are interested in and make a little extra money on the side.  If you stay in the position for long enough, there is an option for 30 hour positions that pay 50% tuition.
cons: For being a religious institution, it was shocking that I met the most morally corrupt people in my life at that university.  They cared so much more about image then the general right and wrong.  Some of the harassment from management made it really difficult to be a student at times.  A lot of the experience depends on the department and job.  The Cashier's office, IT department, and Library were all pretty bad places to work.  If you land a position in the athletics, sciences, or business office, the people are a lot more respectful to students and try to keep your workload in mind.

pros: Gain experience working on campus, with no commute. Easy to get hours in between classes, etc depending on job type.
cons: Pay is horrendous, essentially minimum wage. For some student worker jobs it's to be expected, while other positions include much more responsibility and benefit the University significantly are not compensated accordingly. Most department heads are not empowered to carry out their mission without micromanagement from the upper leadership of the university. This "dictatorship" model does not yield itself well to excellence or growth as the amount of employee "ownership" is minimal and its all about doing it the way things have always been done.

review_title: The honesty and care management shows the staff gives employees drive to succeed and encourages integrity to advance.
pros:
- Entry level positions in Technology dept. give student workers invaluable hands on experience
- Encouraging yet motivating management pushes employees to do better than average on the job
- Work is always happening and even when it is quiet, there are tasks to be worked
- Management works with your school schedule to strike a balance between them 
- Hard working student workers get the chance to tackle upper-level projects
cons:
- Lazy student workers leave more work for the few employees who are driven to finish tasks
- Busy work can take away from time to work on other tasks
- Rude faculty and staff can be difficult to work with while troubleshooting their technology
- Some policies restrict growth and learning rather than encourage it

review_title: Incredible People, Opportunities for Professional Development
job_title: Residence Hall Director in Dallas, TX
pros:
The people at DBU are what make it such a wonderful place to work. People were collaborative, creative, and driven. Fellow staff members are encouraging to one another. 

DBU takes care of their Faculty & Staff in regard to compensation & benefits. There is a health initiative where you can make some extra cash, also tuition remission for full-time staff. Health benefits are significant for the individual.
cons:
The work/life balance in the Resident Director role can be hard to find. Living & working on campus is an adjustment not to take lightly. I think there are more procedural things that can be done to help full-time staff with that.

I think there is room for growth in regard to professional/personal development. It's easy to see younger full-time staff not feel as trusted or as empowered. For many of them, it's their first full-time job. This should create an opportunity to steward their time at DBU well.

pros: Everyone is nice and helpful.  It's a christian envirnoment so everyone is friendly and is generous with helping you in a personal crisis or at work.  There are benefits to working there, you get %100 tuition paid.
cons: You cannot make mistakes in your personal life, for you a judged for it.  You must be a member of a Baptist church in order to be a full time employee.  A lot of people are sheltered and live their lives in a bubble, where others drink, smoke, sleep around, do drugs but lie with a smile on their face.  You must be able to suck up to the leadership to get ANYWHERE!

pros: Good 401(b) matching program, good medical insurance at the time.
cons:
Depends on the college or department you work for but, generally, a very rigid and highly political office atmosphere - anyone who is of a different mindset automatically becomes an outsider. 
For the almost 10 years I was there, the whole campus had to work every Christmas EVE - apparently, this is not a Holiday, for this "Christian" university. Secular companies honor it but DBU enrollment departments - not... Go figure! ... Greedy, much?  :/

review_title: Good if you're in a sheltered department; bad if you're an external hire or value independent thought
Great people who love students and want to help them succeed in life.
pros:
There are some really great opportunities at DBU to network and grow personally.
Easy for students to work on campus.
cons:
Poor management from the top down.
Many dual personalities - Jeckle and Hyde.
My director is terrible about being consistent and rarely stays at work for a full day. 
Also, I never truly felt appreciated - management seems fake and flaky.

pros: The heart the University for its mission statement is evident. Co-workers are great to work with and feels so much like a family. Very family oriented which allows for great work/life balance. Also very reasonable when it comes to vacation and sick leave. They know how to take care of their employees and you feel like you are really a part of something.
cons: Some departments can be stressful especially when it comes to communication but things normally get resolved and a timely manner.

pros: 100% tuition benefit for self and immediate family. Faith based non-profit with opportunities to attend bible studies and grow spiritually.
cons: Low pay,  but tuition benefit can make up the difference, especially if you have multiple people in your family taking advantage of that benefit.

review_title: DBU is a great place to start out as a Student.
pros: DBU's pros consist of: on campus work, easy to split time between work and school, good mentorship and training, good place to start out while finishing education.
cons: Some of the downsides at DBU include: Low salary, no room to advance, sometimes stressful, high expectations for minimum wage. Sometimes irregular hours.

pros:
Safe and Christian environment.
Overall really good people to work with.
Central location.
cons: Overall, the hourly and salaries are low. For some people, this is compensated for with a tuition remission benefit. However, there is no supplement given to compensate for the low salary once you graduate. There is a small raise, but it does not match the benefit of tuition remission.

review_title: DBU is overall a good university to work for
pros: Great Christian work environment with wonderful people; beautiful campus; atmosphere of academic freedom; promotes servant leadership; administration, faculty and staff genuinely care about the students.
cons: Limited opportunities for professional growth and career advancement; compensation range compared to similar jobs in the same area is on the low side

pros: My supervisors and co-workers were wonderful. Everyone truly cares about each other and the students at the university. The work hours were 8-5 and I was never expected to work outside of those hours.
cons: It tends to get a bit gossipy at times, but a lot of that is out of true concern for co-workers.

review_title: Good starting job, frustrating place to work
pros: There are many kind people to work with and you will enjoy the relationships
cons: Pay is terrible, particularly for how much they make you work. Favoritism is rampant and the top down structure is more like the military than your average modern day american corporation. The tyranny of the urgent dominates the culture at DBU and can create a toxic environment with unrealistic expectations.

review_title: One learns to be a servant leader for the world.
pros: The school boasts of servant leadership-oriented faculty and staff, a Christ-centered and Bible-centered atmosphere. It also offers many activities from which students can choose.
cons: There's some noise in the quiet zone when one tries to focus on studying. Another area for improvement is lack of books and study area.

pros: Beautiful campus, full benefits, tuition remission, higher Ed experience, some great colleagues and students, flexible depending on the department
cons: frequent pressure to donate towards building and scholarships, low pay (especially once tuition remission tax starts getting deducted from your paycheck), few opportunities for promotion

- flexible hours

cons: At times less experienced leaders are put in important roles due to limited funding.

pros: You always have something new to do each day! whether it be working on the Farm across the street, or mowing the CMB (Chapel, Mahlor, Bookstore.).
